oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Father Ryan High School, City Beautiful Scrapbooks, 1959, Vol. 1 p. 91
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of the entrance to Father Ryan High School, located at 2300 Elliston Place, 1959. The building was originally constructed circa 1928-29 on land that was once a part of the Elliston family plantation. The Roman Catholic school was named in honor of Father Abram J. Ryan, a beloved 19th century Southern priest and poet. The school traces its historical roots to the Nashville Catholic High School for Boys that opened in September 1925 at 2015 West End Avenue. The Elliston Place campus was active as a parochial school for over sixty years and was the first of two schools in Tennessee to integrate. In 1970, there was an expansion to facilities, when it absorbed Cathedral High School and became Nashville's only coeducational parochial school. In need of further expansion and modernization, the last graduation was held at the Elliston Place campus in the Spring of 1991. During the summer, the school relocated to a new campus located at 700 NOrwood Drive in the Oak Hill area of Nashville. The old school building at Elliston Place was razed circa 1995. Photographer unknown. Photograph used by the City Beautiful Commission of Nashville, Tennessee, 1959. The City Beautiful Commission was established by the Mayor and City Council in June of 1953, for the purpose of improving the sanitation, cleanliness, and overall appearance of the City of Nashville. The Commission later became a division of Metro Parks in 1975, and then a part of the Metro Public Works division in 2005. Forms part of the City Beautiful Commission Scrapbook Collection. 1 photograph : b & w.
